chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reform should aim to make presidential elections reflect the broad will of voters while preserving a meaningful role for states and avoiding rules that push campaigns into only a few battlegrounds. A practical compromise is to end winner-take-all by adopting proportional or multi-district elector allocation with anti-gerrymandering safeguards, alongside clear national baseline standards for ballot access, audits, recounts, and certification. If the country moves toward a national popular vote through an interstate compact or amendment, it should include uniform counting rules and a transparent close-election process so results are trusted across regions and parties.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: A practical reform should make the presidential outcome track the voters’ will more closely while keeping a meaningful state role and avoiding chaos in close elections. The strongest common ground is to reduce winner-take-all distortions—through proportional allocation of electors (or a carefully designed National Popular Vote compact with broad buy-in)—paired with clear, uniform nationwide standards for ballot access, recounts, audits, and elector certification. The goal is a transparent, predictable system where every vote matters, smaller communities aren’t ignored, and results are trusted across party lines.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Any reform to the Electoral College should make outcomes track the will of voters more closely while still ensuring states and rural communities aren’t ignored. A broad compromise would end winner-take-all by requiring proportional allocation of electors (or a carefully designed national popular vote compact) and pair it with clear, uniform rules for ballot access, counting, audits, and recounts so results are trusted and not decided by confusion or lawsuits. If district-based allocation is used, it should include strong anti-gerrymandering safeguards so the map doesn’t outweigh the voters.
